name: Vrsd 2 : 1
description: Change is constant. With new elections we bring new expectations and all the histories we've been carrying. This season is always exciting for me. I have thought about this image and poem a lot in the last four years. History, in the making, has never been easy. There is euphoria of captured moments. But there is always work to be done. That's the message I took from that clear November night four years ago. And it's the same message I hold today. Postmarked November 6, 2008 We want what only the weather can give. Pushing us toward inertia. All my uncles scraping off bohemian mud from their boots & brows. 1968-a typical workday Dan Rather got mugged and my father just redirected down Lakeshore. Following my future footsteps in Grant Park. Broke and rebuilt myself. Dust off my broadening shoulder. My often sudden surprise - to find stars through street lights. ___________________________________________________ T-shirts hand screened with eco-friendly inks on American Apparel Tri-blend Track unisex tshirts. Sizes available are-Small, Medium, Large, & X-Large.

name: Vrsd I : 4
description: Round up the usual suspects for this film noir inspired Tshirt hand screened with eco-friendly inks on American Apparel 50/50 poly-cotton blend unisex tshirts. Sizes available are-Small, Medium, Large, & X-Large. The Mentor Brick fisted & cerebral. Frowning in tones. Don’t mean to be a bastard but I guess I do. faking jabs— sucker punched & duped It’s my way or that way and that way ends things. You can dust it now but I’m making the rules and I’ve got your nose on a hook. The payoff? Well, it’s all a matter of semantics… your cut’s been spent already. ___________________________________________________ This poem serves as a wake up call to myself. I look at my own writing personae as a character in a noir film who doesn't take any bull and is always quick with a well-timed and dagger-sharp jab to the place where I least expect it but need it the most. It also helps that my favorite genre of movie is the heist or long con noir themes. Those films always have an elder leading the novice. A power struggle increases the dramatic tension within the film. Within my life, it is my writing potential that is always leading, instigating, and punching me to do more. And sometimes, as in good noir films, I'm always one step behind a double cross.

name: Vrsd I : 3
description: Emotions run deep in this jellyfish themed Tshirt hand screened with eco-friendly inks on American Apparel Tri-blend Track unisex tshirts. Sizes available are-Medium & X-Large. The Squid & the Whale She eels through my time. A moisture lean on the inside of my open window. Grey cephalopods waltzing with sperm whales. A battle between air and elusive rights. Trust among deep predators. Her beautiful mystery photographed at a glimpse. a second an oyster’s pearl Wishing invertebrate motions. Jelly-like sprints across the Marina Trench. She nervously laughs setting off small tsunamis in uncharted waters. ___________________________________________________ This is a love poem. I used the classic struggle between giant sea creatures to portray the effort to find love with another. The line sums up that emotion. In the instinctual search to find someone to love there is a trust that is given but also guarded. This design is one I wanted to get right before I set it to print. I photographed the jellyfish at the Shedd Aquarium in Chicago. I decided on three colors for this design to make the line stand out as a statement of fact shinning in the dark waters we all swim through on the search for love.

name: Vrsd I : 2
description: Show your love or tongue-in-cheek appreciation for Nashville with this Tshirt hand screened with eco-friendly inks on American Apparel 50/50 poly-cotton blend unisex tshirts. Sizes available are-Small, Medium, Large, & X-Large. Coffee/Bars I. Croissants are awkward to eat. To eat alone enhances embarrassment. Feigned interest in a book. Comfort comes when mastered. Stale bread & words can start religions. II. A purpose for art in coffee shops— places to focus when staring off into space. Journaling long hand brings attention from people using laptops. What happened to Eva Hesse? Her eyes and my met glance. III. Nashville is not New York. New York may as well be Tokyo. Nashville is not Birmingham. Planning a weekend, an inconvenient necessity. I am in this state. I am the Capitol. IV. Reading Harper’s between mouthfuls of New Castle and chips. An algonquin table for one. Contributing to the delinquency of the near middle aged. Confessionals are only given to interested barkeeps. ___________________________________________________ Nashville is not New York. That is pretty obvious. It is much more. I lived in Music City for 4 good years. I made a wealth of friends and it is still a city I would happily return to visit. Most southern cities get a reputation for not having what New York, Chicago, or Los Angeles has to offer in things to do. When I first moved to Nashville and after a hard relationship split I wrote Coffee/Bars to capture the mood I was in at the time. The building featured is a downtown landmark familiar to most Nashvillians and one that, I hope, presents a hopeful future for this beloved former city of mine. The poem may have a sad theme but there is a humorous undertone that, I believe, is in every sad song belted out in Nashville's music scene...which doesn't always involve country.

name: Vrsd I : 1
description: Chicago's famous skyline featured in Versed Apparel's premiere Tshirt design. Hand screened with eco-friendly inks on American Apparel 50/50 poly-cotton blend unisex tshirts. Sizes available are-Small, Medium, Large, & X-Large. Saturday Morning All I need right now. Dawn and a silent hung over panoramic. My tendons ache for coffee. 4 am bars give way to bagel deliveries and the warm scent of Blommer's semi-sweet chocolate. My favorite time when not asleep. I own the Wells Street Bridge. And my castles--Sears, Trib, & Sun tell the world below there will be no work done today. Be at rest with me, Chicago. Wake only when jostled and scold any bright eyed intentions. ___________________________________________________ The photograph was taken on the Kinzie Street bridge looking south onto Chicago's world famous cityscape. I wrote the poem on one of my regular El train rides very early on a Saturday morning. The image and the poem conveys a longing for all the bustling of a city to ease up and take a breather.
